Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Communicate and offer small mutual help like receiving packages or checking in during emergencies
Situation2: A delivery is expected this afternoon while I will be at home and the neighbor often misses packages.
Story: As I sit at the kitchen table, my stepdad tosses out ideas for our weekend—maybe a hike, maybe a movie night. My mom looks at me, expecting me to chime in, to show I’m part of this family, not just a guest. I nod, trying to seem enthusiastic, but my phone buzzes with a message from Mrs. Lee next door. She’s asking if I can keep an eye out for her package this afternoon; she’s at work and it’s something important. I glance at the clock. The family meeting will probably stretch into the afternoon, and I know my stepdad wants us all together, no distractions. But Mrs. Lee has always been kind, watering our plants when we’re away, and I don’t want to let her down. My heart pounds as I try to figure out how to be a good step-sibling and a good neighbor at the same time, feeling the pressure of both roles pulling me in opposite directions.
